Literature Review: The COVID-19 pandemic has been a litmus test for the resilience of the global financial system, revealing both strengths and vulnerabilities. This literature review explores the macro-financial stability during the COVID-19 crisis, focusing on the role of monetary and financial policies, and their implications for future financial stability. The pandemic triggered an unprecedented global economic downturn, with significant disruptions in financial markets. However, the financial system demonstrated remarkable resilience, largely due to the swift and decisive actions of major central banks. These actions included cutting interest rates to historic lows, implementing quantitative easing programs, and introducing liquidity support measures to ensure the flow of credit to the real economy (BIS, 2020). Such measures were crucial in stabilizing financial markets and preventing a deeper economic crisis. The role of monetary policy in mitigating the economic fallout of the pandemic has been widely acknowledged. Central banks around the world adopted an accommodative stance, which helped to ease financial conditions and support economic recovery (IMF, 2021). However, the prolonged use of monetary policy support has raised concerns about potential unintended consequences, including the risk of asset bubbles and excessive risk-taking in financial markets (Carstens, 2021). The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of a comprehensive approach to financial regulation. While targeted regulatory measures have been effective in addressing specific vulnerabilities, there is a growing recognition of the need for a broader regulatory framework that can enhance the resilience of the financial system as a whole (FSB, 2020). Emerging markets faced particular challenges during the pandemic, including capital outflows and currency depreciation. The policy responses in these economies have been constrained by limited fiscal space and less developed financial markets. Nonetheless, some emerging markets have successfully implemented innovative policy measures to stabilize their financial systems and support economic recovery (World Bank, 2021). The COVID-19 crisis has underscored the importance of international cooperation in maintaining global financial stability. The coordinated actions of central banks and international financial institutions have been instrumental in providing liquidity support and stabilizing global financial markets (G20, 2020). Looking ahead, the lessons learned from the pandemic will be crucial in shaping future policy responses to financial crises. There is a need for continued vigilance and proactive measures to address emerging risks and vulnerabilities in the financial system. The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of building more resilient financial systems that can withstand future shocks (OECD, 2021). In conclusion, the COVID-19 crisis has been a stark reminder of the critical role of monetary and financial policies in ensuring macro-financial stability. While the policy responses to the pandemic have been largely successful in stabilizing the financial system, they have also brought to light some potential risks and challenges that need to be addressed. The experience of the pandemic underscores the importance of a balanced and comprehensive approach to financial regulation and the need for continued international cooperation in safeguarding global financial stability.
